Thank you for sharing this! I got rid of my scale a few months ago, and the change has been really surprising. I struggled with the idea of not knowing my weight, because â€œhow would I know what to feel about myself??â€, (haha).  There were so many days when I felt great, weighed myself, and then my day was ruined because of the number I saw. But now, not knowing is so liberating. My doctor and care team know, and I donâ€™t need to know the number. The number is irrelevant to me and my life, and my worth is not connected to how much I weigh.

Just wanted to say that, because I always felt like the way people treated me meant something about who I was, or what I deserved. It has nothing to do with us, and everything to do with them and who they are.

Ahhh lol, Iâ€™ve been there!!! That obsessive feeling is so awful, like â€œcome on, just do the thing I want and everything will be perfect, why are you doing this to me??â€ My therapist once told me that feeling so intensely towards people (like that instant intense connection) signifies how desperately we want to connect with others, and so we can kind of jump the gun. Whenever I feel things intensely, I try to validate how I feel, like â€œitâ€™s understandable that Iâ€™m excited about this person because I thought we had a great time, itâ€™s understandable that I feel upset and obsessive now because I donâ€™t know what happened and I feel like I donâ€™t have controlâ€ and then yeah, recognizing that dwelling on it is only going to cause you more discomfort and pain (even tho for me it always feels like thatâ€™s the solution). It sucks to shake your self loose, but letting go is so freeing. In situations like this, I avoid checking Instagram, or read old messages  etc, because itâ€™s only going to give the obsession more fuel. Get it out of sight, and then cram your brain full of other pleasant stimuli. Eventually, heâ€™ll fade away. 

Also, try to learn from this experience :) I have a bad habit of doing the same thing...Iâ€™d get excited about someone and start planning our whole lives together and how great it would be; and then if things donâ€™t work, it would be even more devastating. Now, when I catch myself having thoughts like that, I validate the urge, like â€œIâ€™m exited and itâ€™s understandable that I am because I like this person for these reasonsâ€ and then I  donâ€™t let myself go there. Itâ€™s been challenging, but the more I do it, the easier itâ€™s getting. The obsession etc doesnâ€™t happen as much when there isnâ€™t that source material for it.

This is my instinct too. As for staying rational: try to remember that sometimes peopleâ€™s choices have nothing to do with you, and try to focus on letting go of control over a situation you canâ€™t control; you canâ€™t control his actions, but you can control your own :) focus on doing good things for yourself; when Iâ€™m feeling unhinged or obsessive over other people, I try to circle back and do something to â€œstrengthenâ€ myself; putting the energy Iâ€™m wasting (on other people) back into myself by doing chores, hobbies, whatever that will make my life a better place. Even if it doesnâ€™t feel â€œgoodâ€ in the moment, in the long term itâ€™s investing in your own well being. 

Also, good for you for saying you werenâ€™t comfortable yet with kissing! Boundaries ftw!

Thanks so much for sharing this! It didnâ€™t occur to me that DBT courses could be available online, and this is really cool. DBT has personally been a game changer; I have real hope for the first time in a long time, and Iâ€™m only half way through a 16 week course. I hope you find it as helpful for yourself!

Unfortunately I can only tell you what happened/worked for me, I donâ€™t know your full situation or what things are like where you live. Where I am, you can at least see a general practitioner and itâ€™s covered by health care. Iâ€™d been working with my gp for years re: feelings of depression anxiety etc, and so I had a paper trail showing how long it had been going on for and what I was trying to do to get better.  If you donâ€™t even have access to that though...Iâ€™m so sorry. 

Believe me, I feel your frustration and I wish I could give you a simple answer. Itâ€™s unfair and f*ed up that society doesnâ€™t value healthcare and especially mental health care the way that it should; that care is kept behind extremely high pay walls and isnâ€™t accessible to everyone as easily as it should be. Itâ€™s not okay, and itâ€™s not okay that youâ€™re in a position where you feel like you have no options. Like I said, I used to fantasize about getting into accidents and hospitalized, because I felt like there truly werenâ€™t any other options to escape how miserable I was. 

In the past Iâ€™ve been able to find counselling services that were paid on a sliding scale (ended up being free for me because of how low income I was), and have also been able to find reduced cost counselling by seeing student therapists (still completing training). Iâ€™ve also recently discovered free resources locally, including the DBT course Iâ€™m taking now at a local hospital. Maybe you can find something similar in your area, maybe you canâ€™t...but I hope there could be something available near you.

Hey! Youâ€™re definitely not alone, and my heart goes out to you.

I was in the same situation...my entire adult life (basically the last decade), work has caused me extreme stress, daily panic attacks, dread, etc. I used to cry at my desk or in the bathroom, every day. I used to fantasize about getting into accidents or getting sick and hospitalized, just so I could have a valid excuse not to have to go to work. I wanted to work though, to be independent and stable and capable, to have money and live the life that I wanted to. 

Iâ€™m 30 now and have no â€œcareerâ€ to speak of, just a string of meaningless jobs that made me miserable; I was lucky to be able to receive money from EI (employment insurance) for about a year) and spent that time devoted to working on my health. When my EI ran out and I was forced to go back to work, all the negative symptoms above came right back. I tried to go back to school, to learn skills for a job I thought might make me happier...but it lead to a major breakdown instead. 

Iâ€™m now on disability and working full time on recovery. I used to also fantasize about this...but never thought I was â€œsickâ€ enough to qualify. Now that Iâ€™ve been approved for it, I feel like a huge weight has been lifted from me, and I actually have the mental space to focus on getting better. I know itâ€™s not for everyone and definitely not an easy process, but if youâ€™ve been working with a dr/team and have adequate supporting documents, itâ€™s worth looking into. 

Sending you lots of good vibes âœ¨âœ¨âœ¨

Iâ€™ve also wondered about this for myself; I remember being pretty young, watching porn and fantasizing about being old enough to have all the sex I wanted. I think it has something to do with wanting to be wanted.

Hey there! Iâ€™m so sorry youâ€™re struggling rn and feeling down; I know how hard that is, and am sending you lots of love! 

In one of my groups, we recently discussed how holding on to some old/unhealthy behaviours can actually help us to learn new/healthier behaviours, because it helps to give you some comfort and security while trying new things. 

That being said, if looking forward to a nice breakfast brings you joy and helps you get out of bed in the morning, I say go for it! You might want to cut down on fast food/junk in general, but giving yourself permission to enjoy a coffee and bagel on morning that you could use the pick me up is most likely going to give you the comfort and mental energy you need to then make healthier choices in the rest of your day :) and when you do give yourself that permission, try to really, fully enjoy that food without any guilt or shame. Remind yourself that you deserve to be happy, and you deserve to enjoy food. Try eating slowly and mindfully and really pay attention to sensations while eating so you can work on actually enjoying the thing :) Thatâ€™s helped me a lot.
Thatâ€™s very true! Thanks for sharing your perspective :)

Thanks so much for sharing this! Iâ€™ve been slowly figuring this out over the past few months, and itâ€™s amazing to see the changes in myself now that Iâ€™m challenging myself to shift my thinking. The problems arenâ€™t out there, theyâ€™re in here, and only I can truly solve them.

Hey, youâ€™re not alone in this! The same thing happens to me: I have supportive friends and family, and I start to get sad around the time that parties or hangouts wind down. I also feel panicky when I donâ€™t have social plans for a few days in a row, even though I know that I have tons of people in my life that care about me. Sometimes I feel like Iâ€™m not even real when other people arenâ€™t around; like the old â€œif a tree falls in the forest and no one is there to hear, does it make a sound?â€ But â€œif no one is around to observe me, do I even exist?â€

My instincts tell me that the solution is to work harder at making people like me/want me, so that they wonâ€™t leave, and if they do leave it means that I failed somehow....but thatâ€™s unrealistic and the reality is that sometimes we all have to be alone by ourselves. I canâ€™t change reality be denying it, so I realize that what I really need to work on is liking myself and being comfortable by myself/with only my own company. 

Iâ€™m really working at making time alone something to enjoy and not something to dread, mostly by trying to focus on things that I can do alone that I love that I canâ€™t necessarily do when other people are around: like submersing myself in art/hobbies, singing out loud to music I like, taking a bath and painting my nails etc. Im going to have to spend time alone, I might as well learn how to enjoy it and make it pleasurable for myself (although LOL I wish it was as easy at that sounds).

I feel like religion anxiety (among a lot of other things) contributed to my BPD too; something I didnâ€™t realize until I was older, and had overcome it. Being taught as a child that I was always be watched, and judged by God was awful. I was raised catholic, and went to catholic school, so I got all of the info, but because of my (single) mumâ€™s work schedule we never went to Church. I was convinced that no matter how â€œgoodâ€ of a person I was, because I didnâ€™t go to Church, I was going to hell. It got to the point where I considered going to Church by myself in university, not because I believed, but â€œjust in caseâ€.

Sending you and your family so much love right now. Iâ€™ve been where you are; the pain is so real, the fear and uncertainty; but you were there, and you did everything you could to help the person you love.  Iâ€™ll be keeping you and your brother in my thoughts ğŸ’–

Hey! Iâ€™ve struggled with my weight all my life, and have only just now recognized the connection between my disordered eating and my BPD (was diagnosed with both an eating disorder and BPD summer 2019). 

It sounds like youâ€™re putting an awful lot of pressure on yourself, which in my experience is never helpful. Going on â€œdietsâ€, even if it was just wanting to â€œbe healthier and eat betterâ€ was always a huge trigger for me because it felt like so much judgement and pressure; I would always try to do too much, would burn out, and then judge and hate myself for it. 

My advice to you is to focus on adding small changes to your existing routines, and not to stress too much about not doing â€œunhealthy thingsâ€.  Add a walk on days you feel up to it; eat whole/nutritious foods when you can. Holding on to some old, unhealthy patterns of behaviour (like say, eating chips) can help you feel safe/comforted enough to feel up to the challenge of trying something new (like adding a walk to your routine). 

Also, try to focus more on your personal relationship with food and how it makes you feel, as well as the relationship between how youâ€™re feeling and what youâ€™re eating.  Try to eat mindfully and enjoy things. If I want a treat, or some comfort food, I have it and I pay attention to it while I eat so that my brain actually processes that enjoyment and it registers. Iâ€™ve been finding this really helpful! 

Sleep too is huge; Iâ€™d say itâ€™s one of the first things to try and improve, because not being well rested will make everything so much more challenging. 

Hope some of this was helpful!

I have BPD and have (unfortunately) been in your boyfriendâ€™s position. It sounds to me like maybe heâ€™s having times when heâ€™s feeling insecure about the relationship and wants reassurance...but it going about it in the wrong way. (Iâ€™ve done this A LOT). 

If you havenâ€™t already, I would recommend talking about things at an neutral time when youâ€™re both in a clear/calm state of mind. Reasoning and rationality are usually out the window during a meltdown (for me at least). Be honest about your feelings, and give him space to reply, and make it about supporting each other and moving forward. Itâ€™ll hopefully help with understanding what/how heâ€™s feeling, and he can think about why he has those feelings, and see if thereâ€™s anything he/you can do to meet those needs. Making  a plan together that yâ€™all can follow when things get escalated might also be a good idea (like, when I feel overwhelmed or explosive, I need time to myself, listen to music, go for a walk etc etc). In moments of crisis, you can refer to the plan together and itâ€™ll hopefully help things play out more smoothly. 

That being said...if it does feel like abuse to you, I think itâ€™s important to do whatâ€™s best for you and your wellbeing.
